body:
Can you elaborate on why this is a problem?
- Do you use the default `AdminUser` class for user sessions?
- Is  `admin_admin_user_path` incorrect? What should it be?

Sorry about that, and thank you for the quick response.  

Yes, `AdminUser` is used. The thing is we don't use the capability to "admin 'admin users'".  Hence no route and no method.

Besides, we use what I think are the default routes:

``` rb
  ActiveAdmin.routes(self)

  devise_for :admin_users, ActiveAdmin::Devise.config
```

issue.title: NameError when using config.before_filter

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
I'm trying to set the time zone for the admin. Everything is functioning normally. I've tried the following:

in active_admin.rb:

`config.before_filter :set_admin_time_zone`

and in application_controller.rb:

```
def set_admin_time_zone
  Time.zone = "Eastern Standard (US & Canada)"
end
```

I've also tried it as a block:

```
config.before_filter do
  Time.zone = "Eastern Standard (US & Canada)"
end
```

Both result in the following error. My local pow development server fails to start (doesn't even make it to a Rails error) with:

```
NameError: uninitialized constant ActiveAdmin::BaseController
~/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.0.0-p247@moonclerk/gems/activeadmin-0.6.0/lib/active_admin/namespace.rb:200:in `eval'
~/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.0.0-p247@moonclerk/gems/activeadmin-0.6.0/lib/active_admin/page_controller.rb:1:in `<top (required)>'
(eval):1:in `register_page_controller'
```

If I comment either of the 2 attempts above, everything works perfectly.

Here's the [full stack trace](https://gist.github.com/ryanwood/6076809).

body:
@joallard I still don't understand what the problem is. Can you elaborate?

@ryanwood since you're running into this maybe you can explain?

The problem is: under a config without the routes to edit AdminUsers, the dashboard crashes. So, if I do not provide the ability to edit AdminUsers, my ActiveAdmin dashboard crashes and cannot be used. That is the problem.
But this isn't the route to edit an admin user, only to view it. Do you really not want admin users to be viewed?

I see. Personally, I don't really have something against it. Then maybe the issue is that this route isn't automatically made by the default routes? (I don't see any instruction to that effect) Or that there's just no instruction for that. (Is there?)

I see multiple resolution scenarios:
- Make AdminUser viewing optional, by making the link conditional to the route method existence
- Make AU viewing mandatory, and include the route in the default ones
- Warn users in the readme that AA will except if they don't create this given route

I don't know about forcing the route to be created; there wouldn't be a clean way of doing that.

What do you currently have in your AdminUser configuration? When I have a model that I want to be read-only, I do this:

``` ruby
ActiveAdmin.register AdminUser do
  actions :index, :show # Don't allow edits
end
```
I have no AdminUser configuration (as this was not something we felt the need for)

What do you mean you have none? Do you mean it's empty, like this?

``` ruby
ActiveAdmin.register AdminUser
```

Hmm...

A simple solution would be to change the offending line from this:

``` ruby
:url    => proc{ url_for [active_admin_namespace.name, current_active_admin_user] }
```

to this:

``` ruby
:url    => proc{ url_for [active_admin_namespace.name, current_active_admin_user] rescue '#' }
```

I only suggest that because I can't think of an easy way to otherwise check if there's an AdminUser AA configuration.
Okay, I just made that change on master.
